INTRODUCTION
In October 2002, 5 years after the original submittal to USEPA, the RMP was updated and revised. In the interim, the management of the wastewater treatment plants had been transferred from the City of Laredo, to United Water, a privately owned company. Under the new private management, the plant was then subject to the requirements of OSHA PSM, and it therefore became a Program 3 facility. The revisions to the plan included upgrading to a program 3 RMP, revision of the management system and submission to EPA. The revised RMP's were submitted to USEPA in December, 2004.
In May, 2005 the City of Laredo again took over the management of the water and wastewater treatment plants. Again the plants became subject to Program 2 requirements of the regulation and the RMP was revised.

The Southside Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) falls under this regulation because of the onsite storage of chlorine.  The amount of chlorine stored exceeds the threshold limit specified by the USEPA, thereby making the facility subject to compliance with the regulation.  The personnel have complied with the USEPA Risk Management Program rule and have completed a RMP contains the following required information:
A?    A management system (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart A);
A?    A hazard assessment that establishes the worst-case and alternative release scenarios and their impacts on the population and the environment (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart B);
A?    A prevention program that includes safety information, a hazard review, operating procedures, training, maintenance, compliance audits, and incident investigations (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart C); and
A?    An emergency response plan (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart E).
The following subsections discuss details of the plan that has been implemented at the Plant.
RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The plant has an excellent record in preventing and minimizing releases of chlorine.  The emergency response policies at this facility ensure that there will

be emergency response coverage 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  Adequate provisions have been implemented to coordinate response activities with outside agencies, such as the Laredo Fire Department HAZMAT team, in the event of an emergency.   In the event of a release, plant staff will contact the Laredo Fire Department.  
REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The plant uses chlorine as a disinfectant in the water treatment process.  
PROCESS DESCRIPTION
 The Southside WWTP is located in Laredo, Texas.  Two distinct and independently operated activated sludge process trains are used to treat wastewater.  
The existing chlorine facilities at the Southside WWTP consist of a general storage and process area.  One-ton chlorine containers are stored in the area, and the nearby process area is comprised of chlorine feed equipment, including chlorinators and rotameters as well as piping, miscellaneous valves, and vacuum regulators.  On treatment plant grounds, the potential to generate a release of chlorine gas exists at the storage and process area. 
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The plant performs consistent operation and maintenance of its chlorine equipment, utilizing only fully trained personnel.  The management ensures consistent operation by using disciplinary measures for operational deviations. 
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The accident history for the Southside WWTP was reviewed for the period from December 2004 through December 2009.  During this period of time, no accidental releases of chlorine occurred.  
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Management of this facility has developed an Emergency Response Program in which plant employees will be trained in the initial response to a release.  The plant is staffed 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  Plant operators are required to make rounds for inspection and monitoring of the plant processes at least once every two hours.  Once a leak is detected, the Laredo Fire Department HAZMAT Team will be contacted.  
The Emergenc

y Response Plan includes: (1) procedures to follow in the event of a chlorine emergency, (2) information about the frequency of employee emergency  training, and (3) a detailed description of the emergency response training to be implemented.
In addition to providing back-up emergency responders and equipment, the Laredo Fire Department HAZMAT Team will assume Incident Command upon arrival at the plant. 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Based on the hazard review and prevention evaluation completed for chlorine, a list of action items was developed and is being considered by  management to implement, if feasible.  The most notable planned changes include the following: 
A?    Consider the need for an automatic shutoff switch.  This switch would be useful during an emergency when the chlorine supply has to be shutoff immediately.  A remote switch would eliminate the danger associated with plant personnel having to manually shutdown the chlorine system.  Emergency shutdown procedures should be developed and implemented in the training sessions.
A?    When the plant facilities are expanded or upgraded in the future management will consider the design and construction of a containment building to isolate the storage areas from the process areas.  Additional consideration will be given to the capability to chemically neutralize any accidental releases of chlorine.
